Description: Fragment of tridacna species clam shell with incised and painted (red) decoration. Used as a dish. Incised with floral motifs including lotus flowers and buds.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Hera (Naukratis), south side of temenos
Curator's comments: Several engraved shells were discovered in Naukratis. Like this piece, they especially belong to the class of Tricdana squamosa (see also BM 1886,0401.1594, BM 1886,0401.1596), but also mother-of-pearl (BM 1886,0401.1595) and large conical shell (1886,0401.1598). Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, 35-36, Pl. XX, 10-12, 16.

Originating from the Red Sea, tridacna shells probably acquired their elaborate designs in the Syro-Palestinian region; their production is dated to the period of ca. 630-580BC (Stucky 1974; Brandl 2001). They were widely distributed particularly in the East Greek world, including Samos, Miletos, Rhodes and Cyrene (Stucky 1974; Furtwängler 2011). Unworked tridacna shells are also reported among finds from the cemetery of Naukratis (Gardner 1888, 29). Most examples of worked tridacna shells have been found in sancturies of female deities, but examples are also known from female tombs on Rhodes (Filimonos-Tsopotou and Marketou 2014, 70) Brandl, B. 2001, 'Two Engraved Tridacna Shells from Tel Miqne-Ekron', Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research, 323, pp. 49-62. Filimonos-Tsopotou, M. and Marketou, T. 2014, 'Les fouilles grecques', in Coulié, A. and Filimonos-Tsopotou, M., Rhodes, une île grecque aux portes de l’Orient, Paris, 63-75. Furtwängler, A. 2011, ‘Tridacna – warum nicht auch mal griechisch?’ in O. Pilz and M. Vonderstein (eds), KERAUNIA, Beiträge zu Mythos, Kult und Heiligtum in der Antike, Berlin, 33–47. Stucky, R.A. 1974, The Engraved Tridacna Shells (Dédalo 19), São Paulo. Brandl, B. 2001, 'Two Engraved Tridacna Shells from Tel Miqne-Ekron', Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research, 323, pp. 49-62.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 35, pl. XX, no. 16)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WA.02)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.49)
